data: NEURO Ischemic Stroke / High Risk TIA (Transient Ischemic Attack) (without Alteplase) Admission
Verify that an 'Admit to' Order has been entered prior to completing the powerplan (NOT required for direct admit patients)
Do not use these Orders if the Patient Received alteplase
On admission, daily for 3 days and on discharge
On admission, daily for 3 days post admission
Provide patient / family with stroke / TIA information booklet
If patient displays the following symptoms:
Indwelling, PRN, If patient requires more than 3 consecutive in and out catheterizations; RN to assess need for catheter qdaily
Early mobilization and rehabilitation is standard of care for all patients with stroke. Refer to Canadian Stroke Best Practices
Within 24 hours after admission as tolerated
Within 24 hours after admission with supervision
Do not elevate, NOT at risk for aspiration or desaturation
30 degrees, refractory high blood pressure, elevated intracranial pressure
If patient passes swallowing screen nurse to order admission diet and cancel NPO order
Follow site-specific dysphagia protocol. If there is no site specific dysphagia protocol consult OT, SLP, or Dietitian to conduct swallowing assessment
Reason for Consult: Diet order (therapeutic), Review diet, Diet as per dietitian. May advance or modify

Administration of IV glucose (dextrose) in normoglycemic patients within the first 24 hours after an acute stroke is NOT recommended by the current American Heart Association / American Society of Anesthesiologist Guidelines
order rate: 50 mL/h, IV, drug form: bag
order rate: 75 mL/h, IV, drug form: bag
order rate: 100 mL/h, IV, drug form: bag
order rate: 50 mL/h, IV, drug form: bag
order rate: 75 mL/h, IV, drug form: bag
order rate: 100 mL/h, IV, drug form: bag
Within 48 hours of ischemic stroke / TIA, target SBP below a maximum of 220 mmHg and DBP below 120 mmHg as per current Canadian Heart and Stroke guidelines

Discontinuing or holding beta-blocker therapy may lead to rebound tachycardia or rapid atrial fibrillation. Stopping beta-blockers to meet blood pressure targets is NOT recommended, although a lower dose may be considered
Consider holding patient's normal anti-hypertensive regimen via medication reconciliation
Physician to reassess blood pressure regimen 48 hours after stroke / TIA when patient is neurologically stable
dose range: 12.5 to 25 mg, sublingual, q30min, PRN hypertension, drug form: tab
10 mg, IV, once, PRN hypertension, drug form: inj
dose range: 10 to 20 mg, IV, q10min, PRN hypertension, drug form: inj
dose range: 5 to 10 mg, IV, q15min, PRN hypertension, drug form: inj
40 mg, PO, qdaily, drug form: tab
80 mg, PO, qdaily, drug form: tab

If patient has known atrial fibrillation or a new diagnosis of atrial fibrillation:   - Consider calling local neurology/stroke service to discuss plans and timing for anticoagulation   - If INR below 2 and patient is not on dabigatran, rivaroxaban, or apixaban, complete antiplatelet orders below
325 mg, PO, once, drug form: tab, first dose: NOW
325 mg, NG-tube, once, drug form: tab, first dose: NOW
325 mg, rectal, once, drug form: supp, first dose: NOW
80 mg, PO, qdaily, drug form: tab-chew
80 mg, NG-tube, qdaily, drug form: tab-chew
325 mg, rectal, qdaily, drug form: supp
300 mg, PO, once, drug form: tab, first dose: NOW
300 mg, NG-tube, once, drug form: tab, first dose: NOW
75 mg, PO, qdaily, drug form: tab
75 mg, NG-tube, qdaily, drug form: tab
dose range: 325 to 650 mg, PO, q4h, PRN pain-mild or fever, drug form: tab
650 mg, rectal, q4h, PRN pain-mild or fever, drug form: supp
dose range: 25 to 50 mg, PO, q4h, PRN nausea or vomiting, drug form: tab
dose range: 25 to 50 mg, IV, q4h, PRN nausea or vomiting, drug form: inj
dose range: 4 to 8 mg, PO, q8h, PRN nausea or vomiting, drug form: tab
dose range: 4 to 8 mg, IV, q8h, PRN nausea or vomiting, drug form: inj
Full leg sequential compression devices are effective for thromboembolism prophylaxis in immobile stroke patients and can be used in combination with pharmacological prophylaxis
Graded compression stockings / Pneumatic Compression device are not safe or effective for use in stroke patients
Insulin Subcutaneous for Patients Eating or NPO (Sliding Scale) (Module)
Blood, AM Draw, Collection: T+1;0330, qdaily for 3 day
Blood, AM Draw, Collection: T+1;0330, qdaily for 3 day
Basic Metabolic Panel (Lytes, Urea, Creat, Gluc)
Blood, AM Draw, Collection: T+1;0330, qdaily for 3 day
Blood, AM Draw, Collection: T+1;0330, once
Liver Panel (Bilirubin Total, ALP, Alb, ALT, GGT)
Lipid Panel (Chol, Trig, HDL, LDL, Non-HDL)
Blood, AM Draw, Collection: T+1;0330, once
When ordering Urine Culture, Urinalysis Macroscopic (dipstick) with Microscopic, if indicated must also be ordered
Urinalysis Macroscopic (dipstick) with Microscopic if indicated
Urine, Midstream, Routine, Collection: T;N, once
Urine  (specify site), Routine, Collection: T;N, once
Urine, Midstream, Routine, Collection: T;N, once
Urine, In and Out Catheter, Routine, Collection: T;N, once
Consider routine HIV testing in males age 18 - 70 or females age 18 - 50 AND if HIV test has not been performed in the last 6 months
HIV 1/2 Antibody and p24 Antigen BCCDC
HIV 1/2 Antibody and p24 Antigen PHC
If ordering CT Angiogram Arch to Vertex, order Prevention of Contrast Induced Nephropathy (CIN) (Module)
IR Prevention of Contrast Induced Nephropathy (CIN) (Module)
Select US Carotid and Doppler order for patient who has had Ischemic Stroke or Transient Ischemic Attack and is unable to receive CT Angiogram due to renal impairment or other reason
CT Angio Head and Neck w/ + w/o Con
Routine, Special Instructions: arch to vertex
Routine, Reason: Ischemic stroke / high risk transient ischemic attack (without alteplase admission)
Holter Monitor if the patient is not currently in atrial fibrillation and does not have a documented history of atrial fibrillation
Routine, Reason: Stroke, Schedule as: Inpatient
Titrate O2 to keep SpO2 92% or greater
Consider clinical needs and availability at sites. Early mobilization and rehabilitation is standard of care for all patients with stroke
Consider consultation with Neurology, Neurosurgery, Palliative Care, Psychiatry, Geriatric Psychiatry, Physiatry and Vascular Surgery
